title: 107_hr1050
content: The text introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code offering a credit for donating licenses and assets of commercial radio broadcasting stations to nonprofit corporations. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code offers a credit for donating radio broadcasting station licenses and assets to nonprofit corporations. The credit includes 125% of the license's fair market value, 100% of the assets' fair market value, and funds deposited into an operations escrow fund. A qualified recipient is a tax-exempt entity under section 501(c)(3). The new section in the Internal Revenue Code offers a credit for donating radio broadcasting station licenses and assets to nonprofit corporations. The qualified recipient must be tax-exempt under section 501(c)(3) and agree to operate the station as a for-profit venture, with profits supporting non-profit arts organizations. Additionally, the recipient must have at least 3 arts organizations from its service area on its board of trustees and agree not to sell the station to a for-profit broadcaster in the event of ceasing operations. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows for a tax credit when donating radio broadcasting station licenses and assets to a tax-exempt nonprofit corporation under section 501(c)(3). The recipient must agree to operate the station to support nonprofit fine arts and performing arts organizations in its service area or surrender the license to the FCC. An operations escrow fund can be established to cover operating expenses during the recipient's first year of operation. An operations escrow fund may be established for a radio broadcasting station if the revenues are insufficient to cover expenses. Any remaining amount in the fund after the first year of operation will be added to the taxpayer's tax. Special rules apply if the license is surrendered to the FCC. Special rules apply if a radio broadcasting license is surrendered to the FCC. The donor may post a bond equal to the tax credit received for donating the station, plus interest, within 6 months. If the donor does not exercise this option, the license will be auctioned. Taxpayers must elect to apply this section for each taxable year. The taxpayer must elect to apply the radio broadcasting station donation credit for each taxable year. Amendments are made to sections 38 and 39 of the Code regarding the carryback and carryforward of unused credits. No portion of the unused business credit for any taxable year can be carried back before the effective date. The amendments made by this section introduce a new credit for donation of assets of commercial radio broadcasting stations to nonprofit corporations. This credit cannot be carried back to years before January 1, 2000, and applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
